subject: Re: [junit] Re: Individual tests ok, problem in a suite
msgSnippet: ... Well, it s nothing to do with HashMaps. It s because you use the one array reference. So, the second time around the loop, you re writing into the same
messageBody:
James Keirstead wrote:
> /* But step outside the `for` loop and for some reason,
> * dailyActivities gets messed up. The keys are all there but the
> * values are all the same (should be different) and none of them are
> * correct. This doesn't happen when only act_map.ketSet() only has
> * one key.
> */

> Perhaps some one else has had this problem with HashMaps before and
> knows how to fix it. Thanks!

Well, it's nothing to do with HashMaps. It's because you use the one array
reference. So, the second time around the loop, you're writing into the
same array ('act') as before, which means you're overwriting the previous
set of values.

Define the 'act' array inside the initial for loop, and the problem will go
away.

The lesson here is to restrict variable declarations to the smallest scope
that you can get away with.

--
"Software is too expensive to build cheaply"
Robert Watkins http://twasink.net/ robertdw@...
